title: Code review and pair programming
description: You will learn best practices how to perform code review

published_attributes.title: Introduction
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Target Audience

If you're a developer who just joined Netguru you may wonder how our internal processes look like. In this course, we're going to show you our approach to the code review process. We'll explain why it's so important to check other team members' code and why you should ask for approvals before merging changes. You will learn best practices how to perform code review properly and what additional steps are recommended to have efficient and consistent communication with other team members and clients.

This course is based on materials collected in this repo.

You will learn best practices how to perform code review properly and what additional steps are recommended to have efficient and consistent communication with other team members and clients.
This course is based on materials collected in this repo.

published_attributes.title: What is “Code Review”?
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Photo by Markus Winkler on Unsplash

Code review (CR) is an activity that guarantees the quality of software code. 

At least one person who is not the code’s author must perform it and give it their approval.

Some say it’s an annoying practice that limits the speed of the delivery. They are not aware of how crucial this process is for delivering high-quality products, free of bugs, and readable for other developers. In the next section, we will show you more benefits you can get by having the CR process in your project.

published_attributes.title: Why bother with code review?
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Photo by NeONBRAND on Unsplash

Below, we are presenting the list of major benefits of the CR for developers and the final product.

Learn and grow

  • Code reviews are the most practical way to educate programmers, propagate best practices, and learn quickly.
  • It provides a safe environment for people with less experience and gives a chance to more experienced ones to see other approaches to solving a problem.
  • It's easier to experiment with the code and learn from making mistakes, as there is always someone to point them out.

High-quality code

  • Code review ensures the high quality of code to all parties involved. 
  • A highly efficient code review process also includes tools that perform automatic tests for every pull request, resulting in more thought-out code.
  • It encourages discussions that can provide new and potentially better solutions.

blocks.text: Photo by NeONBRAND on Unsplash
Below, we are presenting the list of major benefits of the CR for developers and the final product.
Learn and grow

High-quality code

A highly efficient code review process also includes tools that perform automatic tests for every pull request, resulting in more thought-out code.
It encourages discussions that can provide new and potentially better solutions.

published_attributes.title: Performing a review
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Photo by Kelly Sikkema on Unsplash

We hope these arguments convinced you that the CR process is really useful and shouldn’t be skipped. But how to do it properly? 

  • Do your best to understand the problem being solved and the solution used. Ask questions about everything that's not crystal clear.
  • Leave style-related issues to linters*/formatters** (ask the author to introduce one if it's not present.)
  • If changes are big, try to split the review into chunks, e.g. check individual commits instead of the whole diff.
  • Be respectful. Assume the author has good intentions and they made their choices on purpose. 
  • Provide arguments with your comments, so they can be discussed.
  • Question everything in a constructive manner.

* If you don’t know what a linter is, read this article.

** If you want to learn about the best formatter on the market, check prettier.

blocks.text: Photo by Kelly Sikkema on Unsplash

published_attributes.title: Getting a review
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Photo by mari lezhava on Unsplash

Before merging your changes to the main branch of a project (which most likely should be a protected branch), please remember to go through this list and make sure you've followed all the steps:

Keep your PR short

“Ask a programmer to review 10 lines of code, he'll find 10 issues. Ask him to do 500 lines and he'll say it looks good.” (via Twitter)

Bigger PRs take a lot of time, energy, and focus to review - be kind to your reviewer.

  • If you can foresee that your task would result in a big PR, create a feature branch and merge your smaller PRs into the feature-branch. Merge feature-branch to your main branch once it’s ready. Remember all merges to feature-branch need to be properly reviewed.
  • Keep in mind that the size of PR is relative. Short PR may mean 5k lines of code of formatting or 1k lines of code of tricky logic. Use common sense and try to make it reviewable as a whole.

Provide context

Since your reviewer might not know the purpose of the code, try to provide him with some additional context. 

You can do that by using some combination of:

  • links to relevant tickets
  • screenshots / GIFs / videos of the implemented feature
  • description of the problem, solution, and anything that's necessary to understand them (also as comments in the code)

published_attributes.title: Ask for a review
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Photo by Agence Olloweb on Unsplash

When you finish your job, inform the rest of the team that your project is ready to be reviewed.

  • You can do that by adding a Ready for review label
  • Ask someone who is more experienced overall/in a particular topic and might have something to add.
  • If you're a single developer in the project, ask your code-buddy (if you have one) for a review (you can do that by assigning a reviewer.)
  • Share your PR’s link on the appropriate channel.

blocks.text: Photo by Agence Olloweb on Unsplash
When you finish your job, inform the rest of the team that your project is ready to be reviewed.
You can do that by adding a Ready for review label

If you're a single developer in the project, ask your code-buddy (if you have one) for a review (you can do that by assigning a reviewer.)
Share your PR’s link on the appropriate channel.

published_attributes.title: Discuss and fix
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Photo by Sebastian Herrmann on Unsplash

This is the most crucial part of the review.

  • Once the reviewer leaves some comments, address all of them either by applying code changes or answering. Emoji reactions count!
  • Be polite and explain your choices patiently—fight for your code but be ready to gracefully accept defeat.
  • If you clarify anything outside GitHub, write a short summary. It will help when someone else looks at it.
  • If you plan on merging your fixes into existing commits with git rebase, do so only after you get your PR approved. (Otherwise, the reviewer will lose info on what has changed since they last commented on your code.)
  • Don't get offended - you are not your code.

Source: https://www.oreilly.com/library/view/debugging-teams/9781491932049/ch01.html

published_attributes.title: Merge
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Photo by Austin Tate on Unsplash

Once you get the approval, your code is ready to be merged. Remember to Change the PR label to Review done.

Avoid pushing more commits to the already reviewed branch, but if you need to push a fix or add something to PR, remember to ask the reviewer to review new commits.

blocks.text: Photo by Austin Tate on Unsplash
Once you get the approval, your code is ready to be merged. Remember to Change the PR label to Review done.
Avoid pushing more commits to the already reviewed branch, but if you need to push a fix or add something to PR, remember to ask the reviewer to review new commits.

published_attributes.title: Pairings
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Photo by 🇸🇮 Janko Ferlič on Unsplash

In Netguru we love to solve complicated issues. Sometimes you cannot fix all of them alone, though. Fortunately, we provide many ways to cooperate in order to solve the problem. Don't be shy and ask, there are no dumb questions.

blocks.text: Photo by 🇸🇮 Janko Ferlič on Unsplash

In Netguru we love to solve complicated issues. Sometimes you cannot fix all of them alone, though. Fortunately, we provide many ways to cooperate in order to solve the problem. Don't be shy and ask, there are no dumb questions.

published_attributes.title: Asking for help
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Photo by Neil Thomas on Unsplash

  • You can always ask your project teammates for help on Slack or by pairing. Your problem is or will be eventually your teammates' problem, so everyone should be eager to help. Also, when you are joining the project, pairing is one of the easiest and fastest ways to dive quickly into the new code.
  • Use specific channels for help. We have separate Slack channels dedicated for each technology, where you can ask others for help. Just send a message with the problem description and discuss it with other experienced developers. If the problem is too complicated ask someone for pairing and try to find a common solution.
  • If all else fails, ask the team leader for help. They are very experienced developers who faced many problems. Their job is to either help you directly or to find somebody that will help you.

blocks.text: Photo by Neil Thomas on Unsplash

published_attributes.title: Pairing tips
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Photo by Brooke Cagle on Unsplash

  • Use Slack to share your screen.
  • Prepare a problem description and your idea of a solution, if you have any.
  • Don't be passive while someone helps you, share your thoughts and tips.
  • Don't forget to thank for help, even if the problem was unsolved.

blocks.text: Photo by Brooke Cagle on Unsplash

Prepare a problem description and your idea of a solution, if you have any.
Don't be passive while someone helps you, share your thoughts and tips.
Don't forget to thank for help, even if the problem was unsolved.

published_attributes.title: The end
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Photo by Sascha Bosshard on Unsplash

Thanks for reading this course. We hope the CR doesn’t hold any mysteries for you anymore. We wish you all the best of luck and if you want to know more, check out the Further reading section below. 

Further reading:

  • How we roll - Working with pull requests FAQ
  • The ten commandments of egoless programming
  • Code Review Best Practices
  • Lessons From Google: How Code Reviews Build Company Culture
